definition: system/to control/to regulate/variant of 製|制[zhi4]

sentences.english: In the U. K. a kind of conscription was long in force.
sentences.chinese: 在联合王国，一种征兵制长期有效。

sentences.english: The fifth part introduces the impacts of the recruitment on Russia.
sentences.chinese: 第五部分，募兵制对俄国的影响。

sentences.english: In countries where there is conscription men are called up at the age of eighteen．（call up men／call men up／call them up）
sentences.chinese: 在实行征兵制的国家里，18岁的男子要应征服役。

sentences.english: South Korea’s mandatory conscription has all men serving in the army or the police force.
sentences.chinese: 韩国的强制征兵制是许多男人在军队或警察部队服役。

sentences.english: The military system of Cao-Wei Period was called Shijia system.
sentences.chinese: 曹魏时期的兵制被史学界称作士家制度。

sentences.english: Militarily, the implementation of Fubing, thereby reducing the pressure in people's heads military spending.
sentences.chinese: 军事上推行府兵制，减轻了压在百姓头上的军费开支。

definition: the civil service system/the bureaucratic system
equal-field system of Wei of the Northern dynasties 北魏 and Tang 唐 dynasties
Eight Banners system, the military and social organization of the Manchus between c. 1500 and 1911
style of governing (of minor official)/achievement in office
(orig.) tents forming the offices of a commanding officer/administration of a military government/(medieval Japan) "bakufu", administration of the shogun

historical communal administrative and self-defence system created during the Song Dynasty and revived during the Republican Era, in which households are grouped in jia 甲[jia3] and jia are grouped in bao 保[bao3]
to value letters and belittle arms (idiom); to stress civil matters and neglect the military/to prefer the pen to the sword
